section.title: (Optional) --- Is \lim_{x\to c}f'(x) Equal to f'(c)?
section.p:
Consider the function
f(x) = \begin{cases} \frac{\sin x^2}{x} \amp\text{if }x\ne 0 \\ 0 \amp\text{if }x=0 \end{cases}
For any x\ne 0 we can easily use our differentiation rules to find
f'(x) = \frac{2x^2\cos x^2 -\sin x^2}{x^2}
But for x=0 none of our usual differentation rules apply. So how do we find f'(0)? One obviously legitimate strategy is to directly apply the Definition 2.2.1 of the derivative. As an alternative, we will now consider the question Can one find f'(0) by taking the limit of f'(x) as x tends to zero?. There is bad news and there is good news.
The bad news is that, even for functions f(x) that are differentiable for all x, f'(x) need not be continuous. That is, it is not always true that \lim_{x\rightarrow 0}f'(x) = f'(0). We will see a function for which \lim_{x\rightarrow 0}f'(x) \ne f'(0) in Example, below.
The good news is that Theorem, below provides conditions which are sufficient to guarantee that f(x) is differentiable at x=0 and that \lim_{x\rightarrow 0}f'(x) = f'(0).

theorem.p:
Let a\lt c\lt b. Assume that
the function f(x) is continous on the interval a\lt x\lt b and
is differentiable at every x in the intervals a\lt x\lt c and c\lt x\lt b and
the limit \lim_{x\rightarrow c}f'(x) exists.
Then f is differentiable at x=c and
f'(c) = \lim_{x\rightarrow c}f'(x)

proof.p:
By hypothesis, there is a number L such that
\lim_{x\rightarrow c}f'(x) = L
By definition
f'(c) = \lim_{h\to 0}\frac{f(c+h)-f(c)}{h}
By the Mean Value Theorem (Theorem ) there is, for each h, an (unknown) number x_h between c and c+h such that f'(x_h)=\frac{f(c+h)-f(c)}{h}. So
f'(c) = \lim_{h\to 0} f'(x_h)
As h tends to zero, c+h tends to c, and so x_h is forced to tend to c, and f'(x_h) is forced to tend to L so that
f'(c) = \lim_{h\to 0} f'(x_h) = L

section.p: In the next example we evaluate f'(0) by applying Theorem .

example.p:
Let
f(x) = \begin{cases} \frac{\sin x^2}{x} \amp\text{if }x\ne 0 \\ 0 \amp\text{if }x=0 \end{cases}
We have already observed above that, for x\ne 0,
f'(x) = \frac{2x^2\cos x^2 -\sin x^2}{x^2} = 2\cos x^2 - \frac{\sin x^2}{x^2}
We use Theorem with c=0 to show that f(x) is differentiable at x=0 and to evaluate f'(0). That theorem has two hypotheses that we have not yet verified, namely the continuity of f(x) at x=0, and the existence of the limit \lim_{x\rightarrow 0}f'(x). We verify them now.
We already know, by Lemma , that \lim_{h\rightarrow 0}\frac{\sin h}{h}=1. So
\lim_{x\rightarrow 0}\frac{\sin x^2}{x^2} \amp=\lim_{h\rightarrow 0^+}\frac{\sin h}{h}\qquad\text{with }h=x^2
\amp=1
and
\lim_{x\rightarrow 0} f(x) \amp=\lim_{x\rightarrow 0}\frac{\sin x^2}{x} =\lim_{x\rightarrow 0}x\,\frac{\sin x^2}{x^2} =\lim_{x\rightarrow 0}x\ \lim_{x\rightarrow 0}\frac{\sin x^2}{x^2} =0\times 1 =0
and f(x) is continuous at x=0.
The limit of the derivative is
\lim_{x\rightarrow 0}f'(x) \amp= \lim_{x\rightarrow 0}\left[2\cos x^2 - \frac{\sin x^2}{x^2}\right] =2\times 1 -1 = 1
So, by Theorem , f(x) is differentiable at x=0 and f'(0)=1.
